intro: Chaenorhinum origanifolium var. villosum, commonly known as the hairy chervil, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, blue or violet flowers arranged in a loose spike, which bloom in the summer months. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a mild, aromatic scent, resembling that of parsley or dill. It is often grown as an ornamental plant in gardens due to its delicate appearance and ability to attract pollinators.
